Text.Emphasis: The Secretary of State may provide, in accordance with this section, for fees to be charged in respect of the exercise of functions in connection with immigration or nationality.

P2para.Text: The functions in respect of which fees are to be charged are to be specified by the Secretary of State by order (“a fees order”).
For any specified function, a fees order must specify—

P3para.Text: whether the fee is to be—

P4para.Text: a fixed amount, or
calculated by reference to an hourly rate or other factor of a kind specified in the order,

P3para.Text: in a case within paragraph (a)(i), a maximum amount, and
in a case within paragraph (a)(ii)—

P4para.Text: how the fee is to be calculated, and
a maximum rate or other factor.

P2para.Text: For any specified function, a fees order may specify a minimum amount, or minimum rate or other factor.

The amount of the fee in respect of any function specified in a fees order, or the rate or other factor by reference to which it is to be calculated, is to be set by the Secretary of State by regulations (“fees regulations”).
A fees order may not provide for a fee to be charged in respect of the exercise of a function otherwise than in connection with an application or claim, or on request.
The amount, or rate or other factor, set by fees regulations in respect of a specified function—

P3para.Text: must not—

P4para.Text: exceed the maximum specified for the function;
be less than the minimum, if any, specified for the function;

P3para.Text: subject to that, may be intended to exceed, or result in a fee which exceeds, the costs of exercising the function.

P2para.Text: In setting the amount of any fee, or rate or other factor, in fees regulations, the Secretary of State may have regard only to—

P3para.Text: the costs of exercising the function;
benefits that the Secretary of State thinks are likely to accrue to any person in connection with the exercise of the function;
the costs of exercising any other function in connection with immigration or nationality;
the promotion of economic growth;
fees charged by or on behalf of governments of other countries in respect of comparable functions;
any international agreement.

P2para.Text: In respect of any fee provided for under this section, fees regulations may—

P3para.Text: provide for exceptions;
provide for the reduction, waiver or refund of part or all of a fee (whether by conferring a discretion or otherwise);
make provision about—

P4para.Text: the consequences of failure to pay a fee;
enforcement;
when a fee may or must be paid.

P2para.Text: Any provision that may be made by fees regulations by virtue of subsection (9) may be included instead in a fees order (and any provision so included may be amended or revoked by fees regulations).
In this section—

Para.Text: “costs” includes—
the costs of the Secretary of State, and
the costs of any other person (whether or not funded from public money);
“fees order” has the meaning given by subsection (2);
“fees regulations” has the meaning given by subsection (5);
“function” includes a power or a duty;

“function in connection with immigration or nationality” includes a function in connection with an enactment (including an enactment of a jurisdiction outside the United Kingdom) that relates wholly or partly to immigration or nationality;
“specified” means specified in a fees order.

P2para.Text: Any reference in this section to the exercise of a function includes a reference to its exercise in particular circumstances, including its exercise—

P3para.Text: at particular times or in a particular place;
under particular arrangements;
otherwise in particular ways,

P2para.Text: and, for this purpose, “arrangements” includes arrangements for the convenience of applicants, claimants or persons making requests for the exercise of a function.

P1group.Title: Fees orders and fees regulations: supplemental

P2para.Text: A fees order or fees regulations may be made only with the consent of the Treasury.
A fee under section 59 may relate to something done outside the United Kingdom.
Fees payable by virtue of section 59 may be recovered as a debt due to the Secretary of State.

Text.Emphasis: Fees paid to the Secretary of State by virtue of section 59 must—
be paid into the Consolidated Fund, or

P3para.Text: be applied in such other way as the relevant order may specify.

P2para.Text: Section 59 is without prejudice to—

P3para.Text: section 1 of the Consular Fees Act 1980 (fees for consular acts etc);
section 102 of the Finance (No. 2) Act 1987 (government fees and charges), or
any other power to charge a fee.

Text.Emphasis: The following are to be paid out of money provided by Parliament—
expenditure incurred under or by virtue of this Act by the Secretary of State, and
any increase attributable to this Act in the sums payable under any other Act out of money so provided.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may, by order, make such transitional, transitory or saving provision as the Secretary of State considers appropriate in connection with the coming into force of any provision of this Act.
The Secretary of State may, by order, make such provision as the Secretary of State considers appropriate in consequence of this Act.
The provision that may be made by an order under subsection (2) includes provision amending, repealing or revoking any enactment.
“Enactment” includes—

P3para.Text: an enactment contained in subordinate legislation within the meaning of the Interpretation Act 1978;
an enactment contained in, or in an instrument made under, an Act of the Scottish Parliament;
an enactment contained in, or in an instrument made under, a Measure or Act of the National Assembly for Wales;
an enactment contained in, or in an instrument made under, Northern Ireland legislation.

P2para.Text: In section 61(2) of the UK Borders Act 2007 (definition of “the Immigration Acts”)—

P3para.Text: at the end of paragraph (h), omit “and”;
at the end of paragraph (i) insert
the Immigration Act 2014.

P2para.Text: Schedule 8 (transitional and consequential provision) has effect.
Any power of the Secretary of State or Treasury to make an order or regulations under this Act is exercisable by statutory instrument.

A statutory instrument containing any of the following orders or regulations may not be made unless a draft of the instrument has been laid before each House of Parliament and approved by a resolution of each House of Parliament—

P3para.Text: an order under section 15(7), 18(6) or 20(5);
an order under section 33;
regulations under section 36 or an order under section 38;
an order under section 48;
a fees order (within the meaning of section 59);
an order under section 62(2) which amends or repeals primary legislation.

P2para.Text: “Primary legislation” means any of the following—

P3para.Text: a public general Act;
an Act of the Scottish Parliament;
a Measure or Act of the National Assembly for Wales;
Northern Ireland legislation.

P2para.Text: A statutory instrument containing any other order or regulations made by the Secretary of State or Treasury under this Act is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.
But subsection (4) does not apply to a statutory instrument containing an order under any of sections 30(3), 62(1) and 64(3) (subject to subsection (7)).
Subsection (7) applies if an order under section 64(3) is made which—

P3para.Text: brings into force a provision of Chapter 1 of Part 3,
brings that provision into force only in relation to a particular area or areas within England and Wales, Scotland or Northern Ireland, and
is the first order to be made bringing into force a provision of that Chapter only in relation to an area or areas within England and Wales, Scotland or Northern Ireland.

P2para.Text: A statutory instrument containing any subsequent order under section 64(3) (after the order mentioned in subsection (6)) that brings into force a provision of Chapter 1 of Part 3 for anywhere other than the area or areas mentioned in paragraph (b) of that subsection is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.
An order or regulations made by the Secretary of State or Treasury under this Act may—

P3para.Text: make different provision for different purposes or areas,
make provision which applies generally or only for particular purposes,
make transitional, transitory or saving provision, or
make incidental, supplementary or consequential provision.

P2para.Text: This Part, other than section 62(6) and Schedule 8, comes into force on the day on which this Act is passed.
Section 50, section 53 and Schedule 5, and section 56 come into force at the end of the period of two months beginning with the day on which this Act is passed.
Subject to subsections (1) and (2), this Act comes into force on such day as the Secretary of State may by order appoint; and different days may be appointed for different purposes or areas.
This Act extends to England and Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.
Subsection (1) is subject to subsection (3).
Section 53 and Schedule 5 extend to England and Wales only.
Subsections (1) to (3) do not apply to an amendment, repeal or revocation made by this Act.
An amendment, repeal or revocation made by this Act has the same extent as the provision amended, repealed or revoked (ignoring extent by virtue of an Order in Council).
Her Majesty may by Order in Council provide for any of the provisions of this Act to extend, with or without modifications, to any of the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man.
Subsection (6) does not apply in relation to the extension to a place of a provision which extends there by virtue of subsection (5).

P1para.Text: This Act may be cited as the Immigration Act 2014.
In Schedule 2 to the Immigration Act 1971, in paragraph 18(3) (power to escort detained persons) for the first “or of” substitute “an immigration officer, or”.

P2para.Text: In Schedule 2 to the Immigration Act 1971, after paragraph 18 insert—
An immigration officer or constable may search a person (“P”) who is detained under paragraph 16 for anything which P might use—

P3para.Text: to cause physical injury to P or others, or
to assist P’s escape from legal custody.

P2para.Text: The power to search P—

P3para.Text: unless sub-paragraph (3) applies, does not include power to require P to remove any clothing other than an outer coat, jacket or glove, but
includes power to require P to open P’s mouth.

P2para.Text: This sub-paragraph applies if an immigration officer or constable has reasonable grounds to believe that there is concealed on P anything which P might use as mentioned in sub-paragraph (1).
The power to search P may be exercised only to the extent reasonably required for the purpose of discovering anything which P might use as mentioned in sub-paragraph (1).
An intimate search (as defined in section 28H(11)) may not be conducted under this paragraph.

An immigration officer or constable may seize and retain anything found on a search of P if the officer or constable has reasonable grounds to believe P might use it as mentioned in sub-paragraph (1).
Nothing seized under sub-paragraph (6) may be retained when P is released from detention under paragraph 16.

In section 47(3) of the Immigration, Asylum and Nationality Act 2006 (which applies certain provisions of Schedule 2 to the Immigration Act 1971), for “18” substitute “18A”.

In regulation 22(2) of the Immigration (European Economic Area) Regulations 2006 (S.I. 2006/1003) (which applies certain provisions of Schedule 2 to the Immigration Act 1971), for “18” substitute “18A”.
Paragraph 25A of Schedule 2 to the Immigration Act 1971 (power to enter premises and search for documents following arrest) is amended as follows.
In sub-paragraph (1)(b) for “by a constable (other than under this Schedule)” substitute “other than under this Schedule”.
After sub-paragraph (6) insert—
If, on an application made by an immigration officer, a justice of the peace is satisfied that—

P3para.Text: there are reasonable grounds for believing that relevant documents may be found on premises not within sub-paragraph (2) which are specified in the application, and
any of the conditions in sub-paragraph (6B) is met,

P2para.Text: the justice of the peace may issue a warrant authorising an immigration officer to enter and search the premises.
The conditions are that—

P3para.Text: it is not practicable to communicate with any person entitled to grant entry to the premises;
it is practicable to communicate with a person entitled to grant entry to the premises but it is not practicable to communicate with any person entitled to grant access to the relevant documents;
entry to the premises will not be granted unless a warrant is produced;
the purpose of a search may be frustrated or seriously prejudiced unless an immigration officer arriving at the premises can secure immediate entry.

P2para.Text: In the application of sub-paragraph (6A) to Scotland, references to a justice of the peace are to be treated as references to the sheriff or a justice of the peace.
In sub-paragraph (7)—

P3para.Text: for “sub-paragraph (2)” substitute “this paragraph”;
in paragraph (a) omit “and retain”;
omit paragraph (b) and the “but” before it.

P2para.Text: After sub-paragraph (8) insert—
An immigration officer may retain a document seized under sub-paragraph (7) while the officer has reasonable grounds for believing that—

P3para.Text: the arrested person may be liable to removal from the United Kingdom in accordance with a provision of the Immigration Acts, and
retention of the document may facilitate the person’s removal.

P1para.Text: In sections 28J(11) and 28K(14) of the Immigration Act 1971 (warrants - safeguards and execution) after “paragraph 17(2)” insert “or 25A(6A)”.

P1group.Title: General power to use reasonable force

P1para.Text: In section 146(1) of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (power of immigration officer to use reasonable force when exercising powers under certain enactments) for “the 1971 Act or this Act” substitute “the Immigration Acts”.

P2para.Text: Schedule 2 to the Immigration Act 1971 (entry control) is amended as follows.
In paragraph 4(5)—

omit from “about his external physical characteristics” to the end.

Biometric information” has the meaning given by section 15 of the UK Borders Act 2007.
In paragraph 18(2A), for “fingerprints” substitute “biometric information (within the meaning given by section 15 of the UK Borders Act 2007)”.

For subsection (2) substitute—
Biometric information” has the meaning given by section 15 of the UK Borders Act 2007.

In subsection (1)—

P3para.Text: in paragraph (a), for “information about external physical characteristics of the applicant” substitute “biometric information”;
in paragraphs (b) and (c), for “information about his external physical characteristics” substitute “biometric information”.

Title.Citation: Asylum and Immigration (Treatment of Claimants, etc.) Act 2004 (c. 19)

P1para.Text: In section 35(2) of the Asylum and Immigration (Treatment of Claimants, etc) Act 2004 (imposition of requirements to facilitate deportation or removal), for paragraph (c) substitute—

P3para.Text: provide biometric information (within the meaning of section 15 of the UK Borders Act 2007), or submit to a process by means of which such information is obtained or recorded;

P2para.Text: An agreement that grants a right of occupation in social housing.
“Social housing” means accommodation provided to a person by virtue of a relevant provision.
“Relevant provision” means—

P3para.Text: in relation to England and Wales, a provision of—

P4para.Text: Part 2 of the Housing Act 1985, or
Part 6 or 7 of the Housing Act 1996;

P3para.Text: in relation to Scotland, Part 2 of the Housing (Scotland) Act 1987;
in relation to Northern Ireland, Part 2 of the Housing (Northern Ireland) Order 1988 (S.I. 1988/1990 (N.I. 23)).

P2para.Text: Accommodation provided to a person by virtue of a relevant provision includes accommodation provided in pursuance of arrangements made under any such provision.
For the purposes of this paragraph, any allocation of housing accommodation by a local housing authority in England to a person who is already—

P3para.Text: a secure or introductory tenant, or
an assured tenant of housing accommodation held by a private registered provider of social housing or a registered social landlord,

P2para.Text: is to be treated as an allocation of housing accommodation by virtue of Part 6 of the Housing Act 1996 (and accordingly section 159(4A) of that Act is to be ignored).
Terms used in sub-paragraph (5) have the same meanings as in Part 6 of the Housing Act 1996.
An agreement that grants a right of occupation in a care home.
“Care home” means—

P3para.Text: in relation to England and Wales, an establishment that is a care home for the purposes of the Care Standards Act 2000;
in relation to Scotland, accommodation that is provided as a care home service within the meaning of Part 5 of the Public Services Reform (Scotland) Act 2010;

in relation to Northern Ireland, an establishment that is a residential care home, or a nursing home, for the purposes of the Health and Personal Social Services (Quality, Improvement and Regulation) (Northern Ireland) Order 2003 (S.I. 2003/431 (N.I. 9)).

P2para.Text: An agreement that grants a right of occupation of accommodation in a hospital or hospice.
“Hospital”—

P3para.Text: in relation to England, has the meaning given in section 275 of the National Health Service Act 2006;
in relation to Wales, has the meaning given in section 206 of the National Health Service (Wales) Act 2006;
in relation to Scotland, has the meaning given in section 108 of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978;
in relation to Northern Ireland, has the meaning given in Article 2(2) of the Health and Personal Social Services (Northern Ireland) Order 1972 (S.I. 1972/1265 (N.I. 14)).

P2para.Text: “Hospice” means an establishment other than a hospital whose primary function is the provision of palliative care to persons resident there who are suffering from a progressive disease in its final stages.

P1group.Title: Other accommodation relating to healthcare provision

P2para.Text: An agreement—

P3para.Text: under which accommodation is provided to a person as a result of a duty imposed on a relevant NHS body by an enactment, and
which is not excluded by another provision of this Schedule.

P2para.Text: “Relevant NHS body” means—

P3para.Text: in relation to England—

P4para.Text: a clinical commissioning group, or
the National Health Service Commissioning Board;

P3para.Text: in relation to Wales, a local health board;
in relation to Scotland, a health board constituted by order made under section 2 of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978;
in relation to Northern Ireland, a Health and Social Services trust.

P2para.Text: An agreement that grants a right of occupation of accommodation in a hostel.
“Hostel” means a building which satisfies the following two conditions.
The first condition is that the building is used for providing to persons generally, or to a class of persons—

P3para.Text: residential accommodation otherwise than in separate and self-contained premises, and
board or facilities for the preparation of food adequate to the needs of those persons (or both).

P2para.Text: The second condition is that any of the following applies in relation to the building—

P3para.Text: it is managed by a registered housing association;
it is not operated on a commercial basis and its costs of operation are provided wholly or in part by a government department or agency, or by a local authority;
it is managed by a voluntary organisation or charity.

P2para.Text: In this paragraph—

Para.Text: “government department” includes—
any part of the Scottish Administration;
a Northern Ireland department;
the Welsh Assembly Government;
any body or authority exercising statutory functions on behalf of the Crown;
“registered housing association” means—
a private registered provider of social housing;
a registered social landlord within the meaning of Part 1 of the Housing Act 1996 or section 165 of the Housing (Scotland) Act 2010;
a housing association which is registered in a register maintained under Article 14 of the Housing (Northern Ireland) Order 1992 (S.I. 1992/1725 (N.I. 15));
“voluntary organisation” means a body, other than a public or local authority, whose activities are not carried on for profit.

P1group.Title: Accommodation from or involving local authorities

P2para.Text: An agreement—

P3para.Text: under which accommodation is provided to a person as a result of a duty or relevant power that is imposed or conferred on a local authority by an enactment (whether or not provided by the local authority), and
which is not excluded by another provision of this Schedule.

P2para.Text: “Relevant power” means a power that is exercised for, or in connection with, a purpose of providing accommodation to a person who is homeless or is threatened with homelessness.
In sub-paragraph (2) the references to a person who is homeless or is threatened with homelessness is to be read in accordance with—

P3para.Text: in relation to England and Wales, section 175 of the Housing Act 1996;
in relation to Scotland, section 24 of the Housing (Scotland) Act 1987;
in relation to Northern Ireland, Article 3 of the Housing (Northern Ireland) Order 1988 (S.I. 1988/1990 (N.I. 23)).

P1group.Title: Accommodation provided by virtue of immigration provisions

P1para.Text: An agreement granting a right of occupation of accommodation that is provided to an individual by virtue of any of the following provisions of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999—

P3para.Text: section 4 (provision of accommodation to persons granted temporary admission etc);
section 95 (provision of support to asylum seekers etc);
section 98 (provision of temporary support to asylum seekers etc).

P1para.Text: An agreement to which the Mobile Homes Act 1983 applies.

P2para.Text: An agreement that grants a right of occupation of tied accommodation.
“Tied accommodation” means accommodation that is provided—

P3para.Text: by an employer to an employee in connection with a contract of employment, or
by a body providing training in a trade, profession or vocation to an individual in connection with that training.

P2para.Text: In this paragraph “employer” and “employee” have the same meanings as in the Employment Rights Act 1996 (see section 230 of that Act).
An agreement that grants a right of occupation in a building which—

P3para.Text: comprises a hall of residence predominantly for the accommodation of students, and
satisfies either of the following conditions.

P2para.Text: The first condition is that the building is owned or managed by any of the following—

P3para.Text: an institution within the meaning of paragraph 5 of Schedule 1 to the Local Government Finance Act 1992;
a body that is specified in regulations made under Article 42(2A) of the Rates (Northern Ireland) Order 1977 (S.I. 1977/2157 (N.I. 28));
a body established for charitable purposes only.

P2para.Text: The second condition is that the building is the subject of one or more agreements allowing one or more institutions or bodies of the kind mentioned in sub-paragraph (2) to nominate the majority of the persons who are to occupy the accommodation provided in the hall of residence.
In this paragraph “student”—

P3para.Text: in relation to England and Wales or Scotland, has the same meaning as in paragraph 4 of Schedule 1 to the Local Government Finance Act 1992;

in relation to Northern Ireland, means a person who satisfies such conditions as to education or training as may be specified in regulations made under Article 42(2A) of the Rates (Northern Ireland) Order 1977 (S.I. 1977/2157 (N.I. 28)).

P2para.Text: An agreement that—

P3para.Text: is, or is for, a long lease, or
grants a right of occupation for a term of 7 years or more.

P2para.Text: “Long lease” means—

P3para.Text: in relation to England and Wales, a lease which is a long lease for the purposes of Chapter 1 of Part 1 of the Leasehold Reform, Housing and Urban Development Act 1993 or which, in the case of a shared ownership lease (within the meaning given by section 7(7) of that Act), would be such a lease if the tenant’s total share (within the meaning given by that section) were 100 per cent;
in relation to Scotland, has the meaning given by section 9(2) of the Land Registration (Scotland) Act 2012.

P2para.Text: An agreement does not grant a right of occupation for a term of 7 years or more if the agreement can be terminated at the option of a party before the end of 7 years from the commencement of the term.
This paragraph applies for the purposes of this Schedule.
“Enactment” includes—

P3para.Text: an enactment contained in subordinate legislation within the meaning of the Interpretation Act 1978;
an enactment contained in, or in an instrument made under, an Act of the Scottish Parliament;
an enactment contained in, or in an instrument made under, a Measure or Act of the National Assembly for Wales;
an enactment contained in, or in an instrument made under, Northern Ireland legislation.

P2para.Text: “Local authority” means—

P3para.Text: in relation to England—

P4para.Text: a county, district or parish council in England,
a London borough council,
the Common Council of the City of London in its capacity as a local authority, or
the Council of the Isles of Scilly;

P3para.Text: in relation to Wales, any county, county borough or community council in Wales;
in relation to Scotland, a council constituted under section 2 of the Local Government etc (Scotland) Act 1994;
in relation to Northern Ireland, a district council constituted under section 1 of the Local Government Act (Northern Ireland) 1972 (c. 9 (N.I.)).

P1group.Title: Additional information if party not relevant national

P2para.Text: This section applies to notice of marriage given to a superintendent registrar in accordance with section 27 if one, or each, of the parties to the proposed marriage is not a relevant national.

Statement B is a statement that the person holds a relevant visa in respect of the proposed marriage.
Statement C is a statement that the person neither—

P3para.Text: has the appropriate immigration status, nor
holds a relevant visa in respect of the proposed marriage.

P2para.Text: The notice must be accompanied by the details, photographs or addresses referred to in an entry in the first column of this table if the notice contains the statement, or one of the statements, referred to in the corresponding entry in the second column—

tr.th: The notice must be accompanied by...
...if the notice includes this statement or one of these statements...

tr.td: Details of the particular immigration status which a party to the proposed marriage has
Details of the relevant visa which a party to the proposed marriage has

Statement B (for either or both of the parties) Statement C (for either or both of the parties)

For each party to the proposed marriage (if any) whose usual address is different from that party’s stated place of residence—
the party’s usual address, and

Statement C (for either or both of the parties)

to a person holding a relevant visa,

P2para.Text: In this section—

P1group.Title: Additional evidence if party not relevant national

P2para.Text: This section applies to notice of marriage given to a superintendent registrar in accordance with section 27 if one, or each, of the parties to the proposed marriage is not a relevant national.
If the notice includes statement A (referred to in section 27E(3)), and accordingly is accompanied by details of the particular immigration
status which a party to the proposed marriage has, the notice must be accompanied by specified evidence of that status.
If the notice includes statement B (referred to in section 27E(4)), the notice must be accompanied by specified evidence of the holding of the relevant visa by the party to the proposed marriage.

If, in accordance with section 27E(6), the notice is accompanied by the usual address of a party to the proposed marriage, the notice must also be accompanied by specified evidence that it is that party’s usual address.
If the notice includes statement D (referred to in section 27E(7)), the notice may be accompanied by evidence of the person’s immigration position in the United Kingdom.
In this section “specified evidence” means evidence that is in accordance with regulations made under section 28G.

P1group.Title: Change of usual address or UK contact address

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may, by regulations, make provision about the giving to the Secretary of State of—

P3para.Text: notice of a person’s usual address, if the person’s notified usual address changes;
notice of a UK contact address, if the person’s notified usual address is not in the United Kingdom;

Part.Title: Disclosure of information etc where proposed marriage or civil partnership referred to Secretary of State

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies if—

P3para.Text: a superintendent registrar refers a proposed marriage to the Secretary of State under section 28H of the Marriage Act 1949, or
a registration authority refers a proposed civil partnership to the Secretary of State under section 12A of the Civil Partnership Act 2004.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may—

P3para.Text: disclose relevant information to a registration official, or
supply a document containing relevant information to a registration official.

P2para.Text: In this paragraph “relevant information” means any of the following information—

P3para.Text: the fact that the proposed marriage or civil partnership has been referred to the Secretary of State;
the names of the parties to the proposed marriage or civil partnership;
in the case of a proposed marriage—

P4para.Text: any information included with the referral in accordance with regulations under section 28H of the Marriage Act 1949;
any address of a party to the proposed marriage notified to the Secretary of State in accordance with such regulations or regulations under section 28D of the Marriage Act 1949;

P3para.Text: in the case of a proposed civil partnership—

P4para.Text: any information included with the referral in accordance with regulations under section 12A of the Civil Partnership Act 2004;
any address of a party to the proposed civil partnership notified to the Secretary of State in accordance with such regulations or regulations under section 9B of the Civil Partnership Act 2004;

P3para.Text: details of any immigration enforcement action taken by the Secretary of State in respect of a party to the proposed marriage or civil partnership (including any action taken after solemnization of the marriage or formation of the civil partnership);
details of any immigration decision taken wholly or partly by reference to the marriage or civil partnership (whether while it was proposed or after it was solemnized or formed).

Part.Title: Disclosure of information etc for immigration purposes etc

P2para.Text: A registration official may—

P3para.Text: disclose any information held by the registration official, or
supply any document held by the registration official,

P2para.Text: to the Secretary of State, or to another registration official, for use for either of the following purposes.
Those purposes are—

P3para.Text: immigration purposes;
purposes connected with the exercise of functions relating to—

P4para.Text: the referral of proposed marriages to the Secretary of State under section 28H of the Marriage Act 1949, or
the referral of proposed civil partnerships to the Secretary of State under section 12A of the Civil Partnership Act 2004.

P2para.Text: In this paragraph “immigration purposes” means—

P3para.Text: the administration of immigration control under the Immigration Acts;
the prevention, detection, investigation or prosecution of criminal offences relating to immigration;
the imposition of penalties or charges under Part 3 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999;
the provision of support for asylum-seekers and their dependants under Part 6 of that Act;
such other purposes as may be specified by the Secretary of State by order.

P2para.Text: A registration official may disclose to another registration official—

P3para.Text: the fact that a suspicion about a marriage or civil partnership has been reported to the Secretary of State under section 24 or 24A of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999, and
the content of any such report,

P2para.Text: (whether or not the suspicion was reported by the registration official making the disclosure).
In this paragraph “registration official” does not include the Registrar General.

P1group.Title: Disclosures by the Secretary of State

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may—

P3para.Text: disclose any information held by the Secretary of State, or
supply any document held by the Secretary of State,

P2para.Text: to a registration official for use for verification purposes.
In this paragraph “verification purposes” means—

P3para.Text: assisting in the verification of information provided to a relevant official by a person giving—

P4para.Text: notice of marriage under section 27 of the Marriage Act 1949, or
notice under section 8 of the Civil Partnership Act 2004;

P3para.Text: assisting in the verification of the immigration status of a person who contacts a relevant official in connection with the exercise of a function by a registration official;
assisting in the verification of whether a person who contacts a relevant official in connection with the exercise of a function by a registration official—

P4para.Text: is suspected of involvement in crime relating to immigration, or
has been convicted of an offence relating to immigration.

P2para.Text: In this paragraph “relevant official” means—

P3para.Text: a registration official, or
any other person employed to assist the exercise of functions by registration officials.

Part.Title: Disclosure of information etc for prevention of crime etc

P2para.Text: A registration official may—

P3para.Text: disclose any information held by the registration official, or
supply any document held by the registration official,

P2para.Text: to an eligible person, or to another registration official in England and Wales, for use for crime-fighting purposes.
Information is disclosed, or a document is supplied, for use for crime-fighting purposes if condition A and condition B are met.

Condition A is met if the registration official disclosing the information or supplying the document has reasonable grounds for suspecting that a criminal offence has been, is being, or is going to be committed.
Condition B is met if the registration official discloses the information or supplies the document for use for one or both of these purposes—

P3para.Text: assisting in the verification of information supplied to that or any other registration official;
assisting in the prevention, detection, investigation or prosecution of a criminal offence.

P2para.Text: In this section “eligible person” means—

P3para.Text: the Secretary of State;
the Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs;
a member of a police force operating in England and Wales or any part of it;
a county council, a district council or a county borough council;
the Greater London Authority, a London borough council or the Common Council of the City of London.

P1para.Text: This Schedule does not authorise—

P3para.Text: a disclosure, in contravention of any provisions of the Data Protection Act 1998, of personal data which are not exempt from those provisions, or
a disclosure which is prohibited by Part 1 of the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000.

P1para.Text: A disclosure of information which is authorised by this Schedule does not breach—

P3para.Text: an obligation of confidence owed by the person making the disclosure, or
any other restriction on the disclosure of information (however imposed).

P1group.Title: Retention, copying and disposal of documents

P1para.Text: A person to whom a document is supplied under any provision of this Schedule may—

P3para.Text: retain the document;

dispose of the document in such manner as the person thinks appropriate.

P1para.Text: This Schedule does not limit any other power under which—

P3para.Text: information may be disclosed, or
documents may be supplied.

P1para.Text: A “registration official” is any of the following—

a civil partnership registrar (within the meaning of Chapter 1 of Part 2 of the Civil Partnership Act 2004 — see section 29 of that Act).

P1group.Title: Requirement to state additional grounds for application etc

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) applies to a person (“P”) if—

P3para.Text: P has made a protection claim or a human rights claim,
P has made an application to enter or remain in the United Kingdom, or
a decision to deport or remove P has been or may be taken.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State or an immigration officer may serve a notice on P requiring P to provide a statement setting out—

P3para.Text: P’s reasons for wishing to enter or remain in the United Kingdom,
any grounds on which P should be permitted to enter or remain in the United Kingdom, and
any grounds on which P should not be removed from or required to leave the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: A statement under subsection (2) need not repeat reasons or grounds set out in—

P3para.Text: P’s protection or human rights claim,
the application mentioned in subsection (1)(b), or
an application to which the decision mentioned in subsection (1)(c) relates.

P2para.Text: Subsection (5) applies to a person (“P”) if P has previously been served with a notice under subsection (2) and—

P3para.Text: P requires leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom but does not have it, or
P has leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom only by virtue of section 3C or 3D of the Immigration Act 1971 (continuation of leave pending decision or appeal).

P2para.Text: Where P’s circumstances have changed since the Secretary of State or an immigration officer was last made aware of them (whether in the application or claim mentioned in subsection (1) or in a statement under subsection (2) or this subsection) so that P has—

P3para.Text: additional reasons for wishing to enter or remain in the United Kingdom,
additional grounds on which P should be permitted to enter or remain in the United Kingdom, or
additional grounds on which P should not be removed from or required to leave the United Kingdom,

P2para.Text: P must, as soon as reasonably practicable, provide a supplementary statement to the Secretary of State or an immigration officer setting out the new circumstances and the additional reasons or grounds.
In this section—

Para.Text: “human rights claim” and “protection claim” have the same meanings as in Part 5;
references to “grounds” are to grounds on which an appeal under Part 5 may be brought (see section 84).

Part.Title: Provision relating to immigration advisers and immigration service providers

P2para.Text: On the day on which paragraph 2 of Schedule 6 comes into force the Immigration Services Commissioner must register in the register maintained under section 85(1) of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 each person who, immediately before that day, was an exempt person (within the meaning given by section 84(4)(a) of that Act).

In the provisions listed in sub-paragraph (2)—

P3para.Text: references to a person who, at the time to which a charge or (as the case may be) a complaint relates, was a registered person do not include a person who ceased to be a registered person before the day on which paragraph 7 of Schedule 6 comes into force;
references to a person who, at the time to which a charge or (as the case may be) a complaint relates, was acting on behalf of a registered person do not include—

P4para.Text: a person who ceased to act on behalf of a registered person before that day;
a person who was acting on behalf of a person who ceased to be a registered person before that day.

P2para.Text: The provisions are—

paragraph 5(3)(za), (aa) and (d) of Schedule 5 to that Act;
paragraph 9(1)(a), (1A) and (4)(a) of Schedule 5 to that Act.
